Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Example:
shuguo beghe ge
[big tree SG:INDEF]
‘a big tree’

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
Example:
shuguo beghe ge
[big tree SG:INDEF]
‘a big tree’

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
ni bayang kong=ni diamang=du san-ge shuguo biesi tuoluo bang
[this rich person=GEN door=DAT three-CL big straw stack OBJ:COP]
‘At this rich man’s gate are three big stacks of straw.’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example:
ni bayang kong=ni diamang=du san-ge shuguo biesi tuoluo bang
[this rich person=GEN door=DAT three-CL big straw stack OBJ:COP]
‘At this rich man’s gate are three big stacks of straw.’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Comment: coordination: dai; comitative: there are two markers that could count: =tai or =la, but it is not clear whether there is a comitative meaning apart from the collective and the instrumental

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Example:
da 1PL
dasi 1PL-PL

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
ni ‘this’
ti ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Comment: Not productive: “Neither ge nor si is grammatically required.”

Feature: Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
qimai aguer bulai-di ji-ge=la bang ma
[2SG:DAT daughter child-ASSOC several-CL=COLL OBJ:COP PRT]
‘You have several sons and daughters.’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Example:
bulai=ni khuru
[child=GEN finger]
‘boy’s fingers’
gan=ni xianliang bieri
[3SG-GEN kind wife]
‘his kind wife’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
ana=ni ger=du=nang
[mother=GEN house=DAT=REFLPOSS]
‘her mother’s own house’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
gan saihang bang
[3SG beautiful OBJ:COP]
‘She’s beautiful.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
khara quequer erjige ge
[black lame donkey SG:INDEF]
‘a black lame donkey’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
ni muni aguer=ni ala ge-jiang
[this 1SG:GEN daughter=ACC kill do-OBJ.PFV]
‘It killed my daughter.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: nonpast, although it is constantly glossed as FUT
Detailed comment:
-ku-ni-ang
[-IPFV-NONPST-OBJ]
“In Mangghuer, then, the difference between the forms -ni and -kun(i)ang, in finite future contexts, is one of speaker involvement.”

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Comment: nonpast, although it is constantly glossed as FUT
Detailed comment:
-ku-ni-ang
[-IPFV-NONPST-OBJ]
“In Mangghuer, then, the difference between the forms -ni and -kun(i)ang, in finite future contexts, is one of speaker involvement.”

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Example:
kelie=ni nangda hu
[tongue=ACC 1SG:DAT/ACC give
'Give give me the tongue (instead).’
niaoduer nangda di-ni bai
[today 1:SG:DAT/ACC eat-SUBJ:FUT EMPH]
‘Today (they) will eat me!’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Comment: these meanings are expressed by auxiliaries

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Comment: "Not only can an auxiliary not have any independent arguments, but no arguments can appear between the main verb and the auxiliary. In fact, no other constituents at all can intervene; the two verbs must be immediately juxtaposed. […] One final characteristic to note is that an auxiliary verb and main verb may proto- typically be considered to express a single event. For those auxiliaries which can also function as main verbs, this means that they are somewhat semantically bleached when they function as auxiliaries.”
Example:
hugu-lang ge, khuergha ge guida sao-lang ma
[die-OBJ:IPFV QUOTE lamb SG:INDEF disappear sit-OBJ:IPFV PRT]
‘(She) said (one) died, a lamb disappeared.’

Feature: Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Example:
nughuai=ni diantou ge-lang ma
[dog=POSS nod do-OBJ:IPFV PRT]
‘His dog nodded.’
tingsa bi qimai=du san-shi-nian weilie ge-gha-jiang
[1SG 2SG:DAT=DAT three-ten-year work do-CAUSE-OBJ:PFV then PRT]
‘Then, I have worked for you for thirty years.’

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Comment: it is the same as the attributive and the equative copula

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example:
taolai xi-jiang
[rabbit go-OBJ:PFV]
‘Rabbit went (home).’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Example:
ni muni aguer = ni ala ge-jiang.
[this 1SG:GEN daughter=ACC kill do-OBJ:PFV]
‘This one killed my daughter.’

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Example:
bi zou ang=ji kuer-ku kerli-ji bi-sa di-kuniang
[1SG thus where=DIR arrive-IPFV beg-IPFV SUBJ:COP-COND eat-OBJ:FUT]
‘Wherever I go, (even) if (I) beg, (I) will eat.’

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
liang-ge aguer jiaoduer qijighe chuangmu-ji hu ge-ji kerli-lang
[two-CL daughter every:day flower pick-IPFV give QUOT-IPFV want-OBJ:IPFV]
‘Every day the two daughters wanted (him) to pick flowers (for them)’

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Comment: "Subjects and direct objects can appear as unmarked NPs which are distinguished by word order, with subjects preceding direct objects, while all other NPs must obligatorily appear in postpositional phrases.”

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: the negative marker appears clause finally only if it negates nominalized clauses

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:
qi wuge lai maidie-lang,
[2SG word NEG know-OBJ:IPFV]
‘You do not understand language.’
bao xi-gha
[PROH go-CAUS]
‘(You) don’t let (her) go (with him)!’

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Detailed comment:
verbal negation: lai, sai
negation of nominalized clauses: gui
negation of an adjective copular clause: guang
Example:
qi wuge lai maidie-lang,
[2SG word NEG know-OBJ:IPFV]
‘You do not understand language.’
“Dangda niangjia gui!”
[1SG:DAT parental:home SUBJ:NEG:COP]
‘“I have no parents’ home!”(she said).’

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Comment: “When a first person subject occurs with a verb over which the subject is not seen to have control, as a result of the semantic character of the verb, subjective marking does not occur”; “verbs of perception or emotion, and verbs expressing actions not voluntarily undertaken by the subject, do not receive subjective marking, even when the grammatical subject is first person”; “Only first person shows this systematic alternation. Second or third person subjects, whether they occur with control or non-control verbs, normally trigger the objective perspective marking.”

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Comment: it is a secondary function of the imperfective aspect marker

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Example:
qi gan = ni aguer = ni ber-gha-lang
[2:SG 3:SG=GEN daughter=ACC become-CAUS-OBJ:IPFV]
‘You (can) make his daughter become well.’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?

Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Example:
gan=ni shuguo bulai-si=du
[3SG=GEN big child-PL=DAT]
‘her older sons’

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Comment: there are no examples with adnominal demonstratives carrying a plural marker available, only if they are used without a noun
Example:
ti-si [that-PL]
ni-si [this-PL]

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Comment: the noun is accompanied either by an indefinite article, if it is in singular, or by a free-standing plural marker

Feature: Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
gan=ni xianliang bieri
[3SG=GEN kind wife]
‘his kind wife’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Detailed comment:
qimei ACC
qimei(=du) DAT
there is a dative/locative enclitic:
“Semantic roles which may be indicated with this marker include: benefactive or malefactive; recipient; location in space, in time, or in the course of an event; goal of movement or speaking; and impersonal agency. A special locative sense is found in possessive clauses, in which the possessor is treated as a location in which the possessed item exists.”
Example:
Qimei aguer bulai-di ji-ge=la bang ma
[2SG:DAT/ACC daughter child-ASSOC several-CL=COLL OBJ:COP PRT]
‘You have several sons and daughters.'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Detailed comment:
there is a dative/locative enclitic:
“Semantic roles which may be indicated with this marker include: benefactive or malefactive; recipient; location in space, in time, or in the course of an event; goal of movement or speaking; and impersonal agency. A special locative sense is found in possessive clauses, in which the possessor is treated as a location in which the possessed item exists.”
Example:
nige laohan=du san-ge aguer bang
[one old.man=DAT three-CL daughter OBJ:COP]
‘An old man had three daughters.’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Comment: no other means than the ablative case marker are mentioned

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Example:
qi nige dasi nige = sa han qiang bang bai
[2SG one 1PL one=ABL still better OBJ:COP EMPH]
‘Your (secret) is even better than ours.’

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Comment: no other means than the ablative case marker are mentioned

Feature: Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Comment: no other means than the ablative case marker are mentioned

Feature: Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Comment: there is a comparative degree marker, but not in a comparative construction. In a comparative construction a suppletive form of the adjective is used. There are not enough examples with the comparative suffix available to describe its distribution
Example:
gezai-her ruang
[good-COMP place]
‘a better place’
qi nige dasi nige = sa han qiang bang bai
[2SG one 1PL one=ABL still better OBJ:COP EMPH]
‘Your (secret) is even better than ours.’

Feature: Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Example:
qi ri-bu
[2SG come-SUBJ:PFV:Q]
‘Did you come?’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Comment: there is a construction of the type: ’Harald I two-COLL talked’
Example:
chuna dai yehu ghu=la
[wolf and fox two=COLL]

Feature: Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?

Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Example: gan=ni [3SG=GEN] ‘his/her'

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?

Example:
shuguo beghe ge bang
[big tree SG:INDEF OBJ:COP]
‘There is a big tree.’

Feature: Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?

Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Comment: there is a marker of hearsay, it is free-standing

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Example:
ya-ni a
[what-SUBJ:FUT PRT]
‘What will we do?’

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Comment: Not mentioned how mass quantifiers are expressed

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Example:
gan guori =ni yang keli-ba
[3SG extra=GEN what say-SUBJ:PFV]
‘What else did he say?’

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Example:
nige kong china-sang buda
[this person cook-PFV noodle]
‘the noodles this person cooked’

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Comment: the numeral system is borrowed from Chinese
Example:
shi-ji-tian
[ten-several-day]
‘twenty days’

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Comment: the numeral system is borrowed from Chinese
Example:
wu ‘five’
qi ‘seven’
jiu ‘nine’

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Comment: the numeral system is borrowed from Chinese

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Comment: the numeral system is borrowed from Chinese

Feature: Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Example:
ni muni aguer=ni ala ge-jiang
[this 1SG:GEN daughter=ACC kill do-OBJ.PFV]
‘It killed my daughter.’

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Example:
ni=ni berdu-gha bura-ku
[this=ACC burn-CAUSE finish-IPFV]
‘after these things (the straw stacks) are caused to burn’

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: “Subjects usually appear in nominative case, which is morphologically unmarked. Direct objects may also be unmarked, or may appear in accusative case”; “Subjects and direct objects can appear as unmarked NPs which are distinguished by word order, with subjects preceding direct objects, while all other NPs must obligatorily appear in postpositional phrases.”
Example:
bi mamei di-ni
[1SG wheat eat-SUBJ:FUT]
‘I will/want to eat wheat.’

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Comment: marking only the possessor seems to be more typical
Example:
ana=ni ger=du=nang
[mother=GEN house=DAT=REFLPOSS]
‘her mother’s own house’

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Comment: marking only the possessor seems to be more typical
Example:
ana=ni ger=du=nang
[mother=GEN house=DAT=REFLPOSS]
‘her mother’s own house’

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Comment: “Either or both of these arguments may actually appear in the construction, but both may be omitted if their identities are clear from context. However, it is somewhat uncommon to omit both arguments.”
Example:
ning ge khuba di ge-jiang
[this do divide eat do-OBJ:PFV]
‘Like this (they) divided and ate (him).’
mamei = ni chaoke-jiang ma, wheat=ACC
[fry-OBJ:PERF PRT]
‘(She) roasted wheat.’

Feature: Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Is there an initial velar nasal?
Is there an initial r-?
Example: ruo 'to enter'

Feature: Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Example:
que [tɕʰwɛ] ‘to lack’ 
zhuergai [tɕwɚˈkaj] ‘heart’

Feature: Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Example: bi qi

Feature: Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Example:
bi 1SG.NOM
namei=du [1SG=DAT]

Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?

Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Example:
khara quequer erjige ge
[black lame donkey SG:INDEF]
‘a black lame donkey’

Feature: Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Comment: it is not clear how reciprocal meaning is conveyed
Detailed comment: it is not clear how reciprocal meaning is conveyed

Feature: Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?

Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?

Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?

Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
ARM: gar "main, bras" [the g has a subscripted <]
HAND: gar	"main, bras" [the g has a subscripted <]

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Example:
gan=ni yaodong ye yi-ge baowo yaodong bang
[3SG=GEN cave also one-CL sacred cave OBJ:COP]
‘This cave was even a sacred cave.’
gan mori laosa-si = ni mula kao = du yi-ge a lai hu-lang
[3SG horse mule-PL=ACC small son=DAT one-CL also NEG give-OBJ:IPFV]
‘He didn’t give even one of (his) horses and mules to the Youngest Son.’
yima a bi
[goat also SUBJ:COP]
‘There are also goats,

Feature: Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Detailed comment: there is a reflexive possessive clitic =nang

Feature: Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example:
mer liang-tiao
[road two-CL]
‘two roads’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Detailed comment: “Subjects usually appear in nominative case, which is morphologically unmarked. Direct objects may also be unmarked, or may appear in accusative case”

Feature: Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Detailed comment: “if the identity of the particular entity affected by an action is not important, a speaker does not need to use the accusative casemarker, even with a highly transitive verb. Indefinite or generic NPs therefore are often morphologically unmarked when appearing as direct objects’
Example:
bi mamei di-ni
